question: Will Donald Trump say "AOC" or "Pelosi" in an address before a joint session of the US Congress on March 4, 2025?
description: Washington Post: [Johnson invites Trump to address joint session of Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Donald_Trump_speech_to_a_joint_session_of_Congress)
fine_print: If this does not happen for any reason, whether because Trump does not say it or because there is not a Donald Trump speech to a joint session of Congress on that date, this question resolves as **No**. Must happen during the speech, not before or after it; for example him saying it while walking into the Capitol would not count.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Javier Milei Prepares for Speech in Congress After Meeting with Donald Trump**
After returning from the United States, Argentine President Javier Milei is organizing the agenda for the upcoming ordinary sessions. The president plans to hold meetings with his Cabinet team between Tuesday and Thursday to prepare for the opening of the ordinary sessions in Congress. The speech will be televised during prime time, as it was last year, to reach a wider audience. According to sources close to the presidency, the speech will take place at night. Milei recently gave a speech at the CPAC conference in the United States, where he reaffirmed the alliance with the US and made several nods to President Donald Trump. He also expressed his desire to reach a free trade agreement with the US and announced that Argentina will join the policy of reciprocal tariffs. 'If we weren't restricted by Mercosur, Argentina would already be working on a mutually beneficial trade agreement with the US that wouldn't unfairly burden Argentine producers,' Milei said. He also stated that he would be willing to leave the Mercosur block if it was the only way to achieve a trade agreement with Washington.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 24, 2025 02:18 PM
Source:[Radio Mitre ✋🏽🧼🤚🏽](https://radiomitre.cienradios.com/politica/javier-milei-volvio-al-pais-tras-su-encuentro-con-donald-trump-y-se-prepara-para-su-discurso-en-el-congreso/)

**Milei to Address Congress, Discuss Key Issues and Supreme Court Vacancies**
Argentine President Javier Milei will meet with his Vice President Victoria Villarruel on Saturday night, marking the first time they have appeared together this year. The meeting comes after weeks of intense parliamentary activity. On the same day, Milei will address Congress, where he is expected to discuss key issues, including the vacancies in the Supreme Court and the opening of parliamentary sessions. Milei has stated that he will include a mention of the new Ficha Limpia project in his speech, which was not discussed during the extraordinary sessions. He also needs to decide whether to appoint Ariel Lijo and Manuel García Mansilla to the Supreme Court or propose other names for consideration. The President has been advised by his advisors to complete the vacancies through a simple decree, as the only way to do so while the Congress is not in session. This would give him five days to make a decision. Milei's visit to the US, where he met with President Donald Trump, has given him a boost of support, according to his Chief of Staff, Guillermo Francos, who stated that Trump's comments were not 'pavada' and that it is a significant development. Meanwhile, Milei's sister, Karina, will lead a party event in Tierra del Fuego, where she will bless the local leader Agustín Coto, who was a candidate for senator in 2023. Karina is focusing on building the party's space and organization for the upcoming elections.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 24, 2025 11:11 AM
Source:[noticiasdel6.com](https://noticiasdel6.com/tras-el-apoyo-de-trump-milei-retoma-la-agenda-con-definiciones-clave-las-vacantes-de-la-corte-y-la-apertura-de-sesiones-del-congreso/)

**Javier Milei Prepares for Opening Speech of Congress Sessions**
President Javier Milei is preparing to deliver his opening speech for the ordinary sessions of Congress on March 1st. He will maintain his regular meetings with his Cabinet on Tuesdays and Thursdays and focus on the speech, which will be delivered in the evening, around 21:00, as it was last year. The speech will be broadcast in the 'prime time' slot, as it was last year, to maximize its impact. The government will debate key projects, such as the Reform of the Penal Code and the 'discriminación positiva' law, which aims to eliminate quotas for trans people and modify the Identity Law. Milei recently returned from a trip to the US, where he attended the CPAC conference and met with Donald Trump, Kristalina Georgieva, and Elon Musk. Trump praised Milei's work on reducing inflation, saying 'I'm proud of you.' Georgieva met with Milei to discuss a new agreement between Argentina and the IMF, aiming to secure an additional $11,000 million to strengthen the Central Bank's reserves and lift the financial restrictions.

**Trump Announces Joint Session of Congress Address on March 4, 2025**
US President Trump has announced that he will address a joint session of Congress on March 4, 2025. According to reports, all members of Congress are required to attend, and all networks must broadcast the speech live. Trump's speech is expected to expose 'all the national disgrace and secrets' that have been hidden from the American people, as stated by the author. The author expresses support for Trump, saying 'Good luck, Mr. President. Good luck.'

**Javier Milei Returns from US Tour, Prepares for Congress Speech**
After a week of intense parliamentary agenda, where the government secured its first victories, President Javier Milei returned from his US tour and is preparing for the opening of Ordinary Sessions in Congress. During his tour, Milei met with US President Donald Trump, Elon Musk, and Kristalina Georgieva, Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Trump praised Milei's work on reducing inflation, saying, 'I'm proud of you.' Milei's meeting with Georgieva aimed to advance negotiations for a new agreement between Argentina and the IMF, seeking a disbursement of at least $11,000 million to strengthen the Central Bank's reserves and lift the financial freeze. Milei will now focus on his speech for the opening of Ordinary Sessions on March 1, which will be broadcast in the 'prime time' slot, as it is considered the best option for amplifying the presidential message.
Original language: es

**Milei to Focus on 'Anti Woke' Agenda in Congress Inauguration**
Presidente Alberto Fernández's successor, Javier Milei, will focus on his 'anti woke' agenda during the inauguration of the ordinary sessions of Congress. This move aligns with his speech at the Davos Forum, where he attacked the 'woke agenda' and linked same-sex marriage with pedophilia, sparking controversy in Argentina. However, Milei faces a new challenge as he is suspected of participating in a cryptocurrency scam, which has put him under investigation by the Justice Department. This is a different scenario for both the president and the opposition, as Milei's previous speech was seen as a 'novelty' in social and political terms, but now he is facing his first corruption scandal. Milei returned from the United States, where he met with US President Donald Trump, Elon Musk, and Kristalina Georgieva, the head of the IMF. He will focus on his speech for the opening of Congress on March 1st, which will be broadcast in prime time television, as he did last year. 'It will be at night', a presidential source announced to Agencia Noticias Argentinas, although no further details were provided. The debate is whether to return to the traditional time of 11 am or maintain the prime time schedule, due to the fact that the opening of sessions will fall on a long weekend.

**Javier Milei's Agenda After His US Trip: A Speech and Cabinet Meetings**
President Javier Milei returned from his trip to the United States, where he met with Donald Trump, Elon Musk, and Kristalina Georgieva, the head of the International Monetary Fund (FMI). Milei is preparing to give his opening speech for the ordinary sessions of Congress on March 1. The president's meeting with Trump took place during the Conservative Action Conference (CPAC), where Trump praised Argentina's progress in reducing inflation, saying, 'I'm proud of you.' Milei's meeting with Georgieva aimed to advance negotiations for a new agreement between Argentina and the FMI, securing an additional $11,000 million disbursement to strengthen the Central Bank's reserves and eliminate currency restrictions. Georgieva wrote on social media, 'I received President @JMilei at the FMI to discuss Argentina's stabilization and growth plan, which is showing significant results. Our teams are working constructively towards a new FMI program.' Milei will focus on his speech and continue with his cabinet meetings on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

**Trump to Address Nation in Second Term: What to Expect**
US President Donald Trump will deliver his first address to the nation in his second term to Congress next month. According to EFE news agency, the invitation to present the speech was made by House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican, on January 25. Johnson stated that the goal of the invitation is for Trump to share his vision for the country's future. The event is scheduled for March 4, 2025, and the world is eagerly awaiting Trump's vision for the next four years. Expectations for the speech include announcements on topics such as tariffs, deportations, immigration, and cost of living. These announcements are particularly relevant given the recent immigration policies implemented since Trump's inauguration on January 20, which included mass arrests and deportations of undocumented immigrants.

House Speaker Mike Johnson has invited Donald Trump to address a joint session of Congress on March 4, 2025. This will be Trump's first address to a joint session of Congress since his second inauguration.

**Trump to Address Joint Session of Congress on March 4, 2025**
House Speaker Johnson announced that former US President Donald Trump will give a speech at a joint session of Congress on March 4, 2025. 'It is a great honor and a great privilege to invite President Donald Trump to speak at the joint session of Congress on Tuesday, March 4, 2025, to share his vision for our future,' Johnson said. White House Press Secretary Caroline Lipton confirmed that Trump will deliver an address on March 4. According to The Washington Post, the speech is a way for the new US President to share their priorities for the next four years and outline specific plans for their administration in policy and economic areas. Trump took office as President on January 20, 2025, and on his first day in office, he signed dozens of executive orders in various areas of government.

**Trump to Address Joint Session of Congress on March 4, 2025**
US President Donald Trump will deliver a speech to a joint session of Congress on March 4, 2025, marking his first address in his second term. Traditionally, presidents give a speech to both legislative chambers at the beginning of their term, similar to the annual State of the Union address. According to a letter to Trump, House Speaker Johnson wrote, 'It is a great honor and privilege to invite President Donald Trump to address a joint session of Congress on Tuesday, March 4, 2025, to share his vision of 'America First' for our future.' Johnson also stated that Trump's leadership has sparked a 'resurgence of patriotism, unity, and hope for the future.' Trump's second term has begun with a focus on national recovery and strength, prioritizing American interests.

**Trump Invited to Address US Congress on March 4, 2025**
US House of Representatives leader Mike Johnson invited President Donald Trump to give a speech before Congress on March 4, 2025, marking the beginning of his second term. Johnson stated, 'It is a great honor and a great privilege for me to invite President Donald Trump to address a joint session of Congress on Tuesday, March 4, 2025, to share his vision of 'America First' for our future.' Johnson also sent a letter to Trump, saying, 'Thanks to your strong leadership in your first days of presidency, the United States is already experiencing a resurgence of patriotism, unity, and hope for the future.' Trump was sworn in for his second and final term on January 20, 2025, after winning the November 2024 elections.

**Trump Invited to Address US Congress on 'America First' Agenda**
US President Donald Trump has been invited to speak before a joint session of the US Congress, according to House Speaker Mike Johnson. Johnson announced the invitation on January 25, stating that Trump will address the Congress on March 4, 2025, to share his views on the country's future, based on the 'America First' principle. This will be Trump's first address to the US Congress since taking office. As is customary, Trump is expected to outline his vision for the country and highlight key areas of focus in US foreign and domestic policy. Trump's 'America First' agenda includes priorities such as national interest protection, migration policy, energy, and government reform. 'It is an honor and a privilege to invite President Donald Trump to speak before a joint session of Congress on Tuesday, March 4, 2025, to share his views on our future, based on the principle of 'America First', Johnson wrote on social media platform X. 'I am pleased to confirm that President Trump will address the US Congress on March 4, 2025', said White House Press Secretary Caroline Leavitt. Trump took the oath of office on January 20, 2025, and has since instructed the State Department to implement a policy of protecting national interests, as outlined in his 'America First' agenda.

**Trump invited to address Congress on March 4, US House speaker says**
U.S. President Donald Trump has been invited to address a joint session of Congress on March 4, 2025, by Republican House of Representatives Speaker Mike Johnson. Johnson said, 'It is my distinct honor and great privilege to invite President Donald Trump to address a Joint Session of Congress on Tuesday, March 4, 2025, to share his America First vision for our future.' Trump's Republican Party holds a narrow majority in the House and a more comfortable one in the Senate. Trump plans to use revenue from higher tariffs on imported goods to help pay for extending trillions of dollars in tax cuts, but this push is likely to face opposition from many Republicans, including budget hawks concerned about the reliability of tariff revenue and the potential dangers of trade wars.

**Trump Invited to Address Joint Session of Congress on March 4, 2025**
US President Donald Trump has been invited to address a joint session of Congress on March 4, 2025, according to House of Representatives Speaker Mike Johnson. Johnson said, 'It is a distinct honor and a great privilege to invite President Donald Trump to address a Joint Session of Congress on Tuesday, March 4, 2025, to share his vision of 'America First' for our future.' Trump's Republican Party has a narrow majority in the House and a comfortable majority in the Senate. Trump is pushing a plan to use higher tariff revenues to help finance a multi-trillion dollar extension of tax cuts. He has threatened to impose tariffs on all imports, but has not yet done so. Many Republicans, including budget hawks, are likely to oppose this move due to concerns over the reliability and durability of tariff revenues, as well as the potential risks of trade wars to individual districts and voters.

US President Donald Trump will address a joint session of Congress on March 4. forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, presidents mentioning opposition politicians in speeches before Congress have been a relatively rare occurrence, especially by name. However, Donald Trump, during his previous presidency and public addresses, was known for directly mentioning and critiquing members of the opposing political party. To establish an initial probability, we can look at the frequency of similar instances. During his previous addresses to Congress, President Trump mentioned political opponents by name in approximately 25% of his speeches. This forms a reasonable base rate for the likelihood of him mentioning either 'AOC' (Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez) or 'Pelosi' (Nancy Pelosi) in this specific context.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Polarized Political Climate
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The current political climate is highly polarized, with significant focus on prominent figures like AOC and Pelosi. Trump's strategy typically involves rallying his base by criticizing these prominent figures, which likely increases the probability of him mentioning them directly.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Election Cycle Consideration
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: As 2025 is not a presidential election year, the intensity of rhetoric might be slightly lower than during reelection campaigns, where attacking rivals is more frequent. This might slightly decrease the likelihood.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Focus on Policy Issues
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: During addresses to Congress, presidents often focus more on policy issues than on individual politicians. While Trump is known for his deviation from norms, the format might slightly discourage personal mentions.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Media Strategy
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Mentioning high-profile Democrats like AOC or Pelosi often garners significant media attention, something Trump has leveraged in the past to amplify his messages. This increases the likelihood of such a mention for strategic media coverage.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles confirm that Donald Trump is preparing to address Congress on March 4, 2025. This aligns with the previous analysis that media strategy might play a role in Trump mentioning high-profile political figures, as such an address to Congress is a significant platform for gaining public and media attention.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The articles mainly focus on Trump's push for his 'America First' agenda and avoiding foreign conflicts, which might suggest a focus on policy rather than direct attacks on specific political figures. There is no explicit indication that he plans to mention political rivals like AOC or Pelosi in this address, which might decrease the likelihood slightly.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To establish a base rate for this question, I consider the frequency with which past U.S. presidents mention minority party leaders or prominent opposing politicians during key addresses like State of the Union or joint sessions. Historically, such mentions are relatively rare and generally occur in contexts where the president seeks to underscore partisan differences or policy conflicts. Specifically focusing on Donald Trump's past addresses to joint sessions of Congress, he's intermittently mentioned prominent Democratic figures as a rhetorical device. Past mentions suggest a base rate between 20-30% probability of such a mention of AOC or Pelosi in a similar setting.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Historical Reference
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Donald Trump has a history of directly addressing or criticizing political opponents like Nancy Pelosi to rally his base or highlight political opposition.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Political Climate
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If, by early 2025, there have been notable tensions or significant political events involving AOC or Pelosi that could prompt Trump to address them specifically in a joint session, this would increase the likelihood. As of now, tensions with these figures are consistent with the current political climate, but no extraordinary tensions have been reported.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Public and Media Interest
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Mentions of high-profile figures like AOC and Pelosi can garner media attention and public interest, serving as a useful narrative device for Trump. Given Trump's media-driven approach, the probability slightly increases.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles reiterate that Trump is preparing to deliver a significant address before Congress, a context where he might mention political figures like AOC or Pelosi to emphasize partisan divides or policy differences. Trump’s style is often provocative, aiming to rally his base by highlighting clear political adversaries, making mentions of prominent Democrats plausible.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The articles do not provide any specific update regarding recent clashes or substantial issues involving AOC or Pelosi that would increase the necessity or likelihood of mentioning them in the upcoming speech. The focus seems more on economic and foreign policy issues as seen with the 'America First' agenda and less on individual legislators, which slightly reduces the probability of a mention.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, sitting presidents tend to reference prominent political figures, especially those from the opposition, in speeches before Congress to highlight political debates, achievements, or challenges. References to Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (AOC) and Nancy Pelosi, as influential members of the Democratic party, have been common in political discourse. Given that Trump has a history of mentioning AOC and Pelosi in various contexts during his previous term, the base rate for referencing an opposition figure in such addresses can be estimated around 60%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Political Climate
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If the political climate is contentious with ongoing debates involving AOC or Pelosi, the chance of Trump mentioning them increases. Considering Trump's tendency to engage in polarizing rhetoric, the current political climate might encourage him to highlight opposition leaders to rally his base.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Relevance of AOC and Pelosi
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If recent events or legislative activities prominently feature AOC or Pelosi, this might make them more likely to be mentioned. Given their roles in spearheading significant initiatives, there’s a heightened probability of their names arising in key discussions.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Strategic Focus
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Trump might choose to focus on issues rather than individuals, especially if aiming to present a unifying message. This could reduce the likelihood of individual mentions in a formal setting.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles do not mention specific plans or references to AOC or Pelosi but emphasize Trump's intention to address 'national disgrace and secrets.' His speech is expected to tackle polarizing national issues aligning with his 'America First' vision, implying potential references to high-profile political figures like AOC or Pelosi to emphasize contrasts with the opposition.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: None of the articles specifically mention any ongoing controversies or legislative actions involving AOC or Pelosi that Trump might capitalize on in his speech. Also, the significant interest in foreign relations, especially with Argentina's President Milei, suggests a broader focus in the address rather than individual domestic opponents.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, political figures such as Donald Trump have mentioned prominent opposing party members in significant public addresses, particularly before key audiences like Congress. During official addresses to Congress, it is common for presidents to mention notable figures from the rival party, either to critique their policies or to address bipartisan issues. Given this historical context, I will start with a base rate of 70%, derived from past addresses where such mentions have occurred frequently.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Strategy
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: From a strategy perspective, mentioning AOC (Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez) or Pelosi could serve to galvanize his political base by targeting well-known figures in the Democratic party. This can be a tactic to draw clear partisan lines and rally support.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Media Attention
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Mentioning a controversial or high-profile figure tends to generate media attention, which can amplify the president's message and ensure coverage in subsequent news cycles. Given Trump's historical appetite for media engagement, this increases the likelihood.
